The first two of a series of six
lectures on "The Romantic Revival
of Poetry in the Nineteenth Century" were delivered at 5 o'clock
last Thursday and Friday afternoons by Sir Walter Raleigh, professor of English poetry at Oxford
University. The lectures, which
dealt with the lives and works of
Coleridge and Keats, were greatly
enjoyed by large and appreciative
and
Sir Walter began his first lecture
with the statement that any study of
literature was concerned with but
two things of primal importance—
men and books. It was for this reason, he continued, that he had decided not to give an introductory
talk on the external influences that
helped to bring about the revival,
but had preferred to enter at once
upon the consideration of the part
played by one of the chief actors
in the movement—Samuel Taylor
Coleridge.
The lecturer dealt first with the
character of Coleridge, as revealed
in his letters. It was remarked that
the laziness and the tendency toward plagiarism that seriously affected the poet's literary career were
clearly foreshadowed in sonic of
these youthful epistles, for many of
their cleverest passages and aptest
phrases were filched outright from
letters of Thomas Gray. Coleridge's
earliest poems were then considered, and finally the period when
the element of the supernatural was
introduced into his work received
the attention of the speaker. It was
at this time that the poet seemed
suddenly to have found himself, for
all of his work that is of any great
degree of importance was composed
during the ten years immediately
ensuing.
Coleridge's relations with Wordsworth and Lamb were commented
upon, his friendship with the former being of chief importance because of the influence it exerted
upon his literary production. The
lecturer closed with an appreciation
of the work of Coleridge, and a consideration of the indebtedness of his
age and of the reading world of all
ages to the great Lake poet.
The discussion of the character
and writings of Keats was equally
adequate and appreciative. Sir
Walter first sought to dissipate the
general, though erroneous, impression that the brilliant, romantic poet
was an affected dandy like Leigh
Hunt and many another of his literary contemporaries. He showed that
Keats was a man of happy disposi-

The Johns Hopkins lacrosse team
played the Carlisle Indians to a
3-to-3 tie on Saturday at Homewood Field in a game lull of excitement and interest from whistle to
whistle. The Indians, although
fighting hard for the victory, seemed
to play rather listlessly, and it was
not until the last few minutes of the
contest that real fighting took place.
Hopkins made their first score well
on ill the game, this being followed
ouickly by the Indians' initial tally.
The ball was almost constantly in
the visitors' territory, and time and
again the Black and Blue men shot
for goal only to be confronted with
a disappointing-looking crowd of
redskins blocking the goal. Carlisle
seemed to be playing an entirely defensive game, barring such times as
when they would momentarily carry
the ball down the field and try for
goal. It was in times like these that
the invaluable services of Stuart, in
the goal, and 'Huck and Brooks, his
helpers, saved Hopkins from severe
punishment.
Many former lacrosse stars present at the game were disappointed
in the way the Hopkins men allowed
the ball to be taken from them without a "fight," but it was suggested
that perhaps this was caused by lack
Altogether, the
of confidence.
coaches were pleased by the showing of the team, and expect to have
a well-seasoned team in condition to
meet Navy and Pennsylvania this
week. Bob Nelson, the big center,
was a little "off his feed" Saturday,
but it is thought that by mid-season
he will prove himself a tower of
strength to the team. Among the
new men on the squad, \Volfe and
Woodward have shown up to advantage and both may land regular
jobs.

Prof. Dudley A. Sargent. of Harvard. does not favor military training for the youth of our schools or
the young men of our colleges, and
he is the best-known expert in scientific physical development in the
United States, if not in the world.
Th:s view puts him at an absolute
variance from Dr. Jacob Gould
Schurman, president of Cornell,
who declares that schools and colleges should be used as military
training- agencies, and who recently
has so expressed himself publicly,
thereby making something of a
sensation.
"A citizens' army for health and
efficiency," he said, "could do more
for our national defense than a
military army ever could do. for
we could include in that citizens'
army every, able-bodied male in
land, without curtailing his usefulness in industry, and his service in it would make his physically
ready for the brief military training
which would be necessary if need
arose for his service as a soldier.
There would be no sacrifice of him
upon the altar of militarism unless
necessity occurred.
"The expense of such an army for
health and efficiency," Professor
Sargent continued,"and what would
be accomplished by it, would be entirely out of proportion to the expense and accomplishments of our
present military force, the expense
being infinitely less and the accomplishments infinitely greater.
"The moment is now ripe for the
beginning of an organization of the
sort, rather than for the beginning
of a vast military organization. In
case of war it very quickly could be
rendered able to protect us better
than an army with purely military
training could. In the times of
peace, for which we hope and to
which we all look forward, it would
add more to our national wealth
than anything else could. I think
a peace army would be more acceptable, also, to the temper of the
American people, who often have
raised their voices against a great
standing military army.
"The weakness of the peace
movement always has been that it
never has offered a substitute for
the standing\ military army, and this
has worried those wise people who
have not wished to see our country
left utterly defenseless.
"Germany's theory was that without militarism her people would go
to seed, become flaccid. But the
reasoning on which she based this
theory took no thought of such an

Although the baseball team has
only one victory, with three defeats,
to its credit it has played well and
has in its first four games given
promise of developing into a wellbalanced machine that can land for
Hopkins the State championship.
The members of the Black and
Blue squad have shown themselves
especially strong at the bat. Several
men on the team are hitting the ball
at a most promising rate. "Butts"
Sutton has only played in two
games, but he has about five hits
to his credit, among which are several that went for extra bases.
Ewing is another slugger. He
made a home run against the Terrapins and another against the Aggies.
Noble and Worthington have also
shown up well with the bat.
Though beaten by Princeton, the
'Varsity put up a good game and
would probably have won if several
costly errors could have been avoided. Against the Baltimore Feds the
problem was to let the Terrapins
get as few runs as possible. Hopkins was, of course, outclassed, but
nevertheless played well and gained
valuable experience.
The team that met Catholic University was in a crippled condition
and did well to hold the Washington team to three runs. Butler, the
star first baseman, could not play
and several other valuable men were
unable to be in the game.
The 'Varsity showed up very well
against the Maryland Agricultural
College, coming out victors in a
hard-fought battle with a 7-to-6
score. It was the batting of Sutton,
Worthington and "Babe" Ewing;
that turned the. trick and gave Hopkins the long end of the score.
Coach Hooper has developed two
sterling pitchers in Phythyon and
Hollingsworth. These two men
have speed and a large assortment
of curves and, above all, can use
their heads. Defandorf, who pitched
last year, and Gorman have also
shown up well and should be able
to pitch winning ball whenever
called into the box.
On next Saturday the Hopkins
squad meets Washington College at
Homewood. Washington College
has a good team and a close game
is expected, but Coach Hooper feels
confident that his men are rounding
into form and will gain another
victory on that day.

(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

Alumni Secretaries Meet.

The third annual meeting of the
Association of Alumni Secretaries
was held lately at Columbia and
Yale Universities with sixty-five
representatives present, representing
schools from New England, California, Texas and Louisiana. The
object of the association is "to bring
together once a year from all over
the country, the men who are directing the alumni work of American
colleges and universities for a discussion of their common problems
— the effective organization of
alumni sentiment, the publication of
alumni journals, and all other
means of promoting the university
interest by holding the institution
and its-graduates in an intimate relation."

(Continued on page 5, col. 2)

The schedule of the Johns Hopkins summer courses for 1915 has
recently been issued. The catalogue shows both a more elaborate
selection of studies and a larger faculty than that offered in any of the
previous four years in which the
summer school has been in existence.
The chief loss to the summer
school will be found in the absence
of Prof. Robert M. Gay, of Goucher College, who enjoys the reputation of being one of the foremost
essayists since Lamb and whose
courses on the short story and on
the novel of the nineteenth century
were two of last year's most popular classes.
One of the most important and
gratifying announcements in regard
to the faculty is that John H. Latane is to give courses this summer.
Dr. Latane will offer graduate
courses in Latin-American history
and diplomacy, in international law
and in American history.
Courses will be offered this summer in biology, chemistry, education, English composition, English
literature, French, German, history,
Latin, manual training, mathematics,
music (in connection with the Peabody Conservatory), physics, playground and recreation, politics, psychology and Spanish.
Two graduates of Hopkins will
come from other universities to offer courses here this summer. Associate Professor Robert L. Ramsay, of the University of Missouri,
will give two courses in English
composition and one graduate
course in recent English literature,
and Associate Professor Asa A.
Schaeffer, of the University of Tennessee, will offer two courses in biology.
Prof. Edward F. Buchner will
again be the director of the summer
courses, and practically the same arrangements will be made in regard
to the credits given for work done
in these courses as were in existence
last year—that is to say, a credit of
not more than one-half a regular
course will be allowed for the satisfactory completion of the work of
any course of collegiate grade (only
two courses to be offered for
credit) ; and graduate courses will
be credited by the respective departments in accordance with the rule
of the Board of University Studies.
The tuition fee is twenty-five dollars, payment of which entitles the
student to attend as many as three
courses. There are no formal examinations for admission.

In the meet next Saturday no distance longer than the quarter-mile
will be run, according to the rules
of the Navy Athletic Association.

in the relay race of this meet this
year. Each side will enter two
teams, instead of only one, and the
event will count the same as the
other events—five and three for first
and second places. This is one of
the hardest events for Hopkins,
since, with her small squad, it is not
possible to save eight fresh men.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 12, 1915.
Shower Troubles.

Not so very long ago a member
of one of the spring teams stood
under the shower in the clubhouse
beneath the concrete stand at Homewood. He had just succeeded in
working up a fluffy lather from a
giant cake of soap and was about
to step under the spray when the
water ceased to flow. He worked
awhile at the spigots, but the pipes
were empty. Covered with soapsuds, he pondered awhile, then became indignant, and, failing to find
the ,English language expressive, began to speak in an old Semitic
tongue, which was a great revelation, as well as shock, to his hearers.
A committee of relief offered him
the little bit of water which remained in a drinking pail, and applying this with a ladle and by means
of a stiff piece of cardboard he
finally cleaned off the lather, and
went without the shower.
The caretaker of Homewood
Field said: "The water tank is
empty; it will take two hours to fill
it. You cannot take a bath today."
An inquiry into the state of affairs revealed the following facts:
That, notwithstanding the testimony
of the caretaker, there was water in
the tank, but that it had been turned
off until the members of another
team, which was still at practice,
had returned for their showers. So
those who had been affected by the

The announcement of an anonymous gift of $50,000 to the University came as a delightful surprise last week. It was not definitely announced whether the money
would be immediately available nor
whether it could be put into that
slowly-growing fund which will enable the building of the remainder
of the University's plant on the new
Homewood estate, but the very fact
that a Baltimorean (who does not
wish his name made public) is so
interested in our welfare as to give
us this sum of money at a time
when so much is needed reminds us
again of the fact that Baltimore is
working with the University and
wants to see it soon housed in
its magnificent new home in the
suburbs.
Fifty thousand dollars might not
mean much to the larger universities with great endowments and
regular -donors of princely sums."
To them it would he only a drop in
the bucket. But Hopkins, because
of its youth and consequent small
body of alumni, rarely receives a
gift of money except from some
educational foundation or under the
terms of the will of a friend. This
anonymous $50,000, then, means
much to the University. It brings
a message of friendship and collies
at a time when the institution, perhaps more than at any other time,
needs money. It lightens the hearts
of the men who are wrapped up in
the "on to Homewood" movement.
Because it expresses the esteem
in which the University is held by
"A Baltimorean," it is encouragement ; and, because it is encouragement, it is as greatly appreciated as
those great sums which are received
by other universities and colleges—
those large amounts which do not
make Hopkins envious, but which
spur it on to renewed activity with
the hope that some day it will be
in a position to call upon rich alumni
to satisfy every little wish and whim.

Ex-Governor William
Haines,
of Maine, has enrolled in one of the
short agricultural courses at the
University of Maine.
* * *
To organize the Dartmouth undergraduates into an efficient body
for fire prevention, a student fire
squad has been appointed by Pal2eopitus and President Nichols. Nine
men selected from the junior class
will act with the members of Palx°piths as a fire squad.
• * * *
To prevent political deals in the
elections of class officers and committee members at Brown, Dean
Randall has sent out pledges, to be
signed and returned to him. The
pledges are to the effect that the
signers will form no political parties
for the election of certain men or
groups of men.
*
Forty per cent, of the students in
the Kansas State Agricultural College get no financial aid from home.
The customary forms of employment are followed and several novel
ones. One of these novel plans
which has been adopted is the purchase of a cow by each of a group
of men, who receive their room and
board in return for the milk.
* * *
So great has been the recent
growth of the graduate college of the
University of Pennsylvania that the
present facilities for teaching professional courses are entirely inadequate, and plans are being made for
the erection of a building to cost
half a million dollars. The site of
the building is being cleared by the
razing of several ow structures.
* * *
-En order to save much of the time
now wasted by students in collecting money for undergraduate organizations, Prof. George Parmly
Day, treasurer of Yale University,
suggests a Student Collecting Association. Such an association would
continue from year to year the policy of efficient collecting, and in connection with the Bureau of Appointment, would assist students who
were in need of financial help.
* * *
Interest in track and field athletics at Cornell is not on the wane,
judging from a statement by Coach
Moakley at the recent track dinner.
He said that there are 310 candidates practicing regularly, and that
he expects an increase of 200 or
more. The coach also stated that he
considered track work excellent
training for those going into any
other line of college athletics, as it
typifies the perfect co-ordination of
all parts of the body.

PRESIDENT GOODNOW SPEAKS
TO ALUMNI OF MIDDLE WEST

President Goodnow left Baltimore last Wednesday on a short
trip through the Middle West, on
which he is to make addresses before Johns Hopkins alumni and
other organizations. Dr. Goodnow's first stop was Cleveland,
where he addressed the City Club
of that place.
Later, on invitation of Mayor
Newton Baker, of Cleveland, who is
himself an alumnus of Johns Hopkins, he addressed the Johns Hopkins alumni of Cleveland. On
Monday, President Goodnow attended the annual luncheon of the
Hopkins alumni of the Middle
West.
It is expected that through this
trip a new interest in the presentday Johns Hopkins and its activities will be created throughout the
sections in which alumni are located,
especially in view of the reconstructive period through which the University is now passing.
From the West, President Goodnow will go, later in the week, to
New York and will return to Baltimore shortly thereafter.

New York City's million-dollar
twenty-story Yale clubhouse is now
practically completed. This building, located at Vanderbilt avenue
and Forty-fourth street, wil soon be
the headquarters of all Yale men in
New York.
The main entrance to the buildnig is of simple design and the
ground floor will be used as an entrance hall and for offices. The
second floor contains a large social
hall—one of the noblest in New
York City. The third floor is given
up to billiard and grill rooms, the
fourth to a library, the fifth to the
swimming- pool and baths, the sixth
to the gymnasium and squash courts,
the seventh to a valeting- equipment.
Then follow ten floors of bedrooms.
The eighteenth floor contains numerous private dining-rooms of different sizes. Floor nineteen is the
kitchen department; floor twenty is
the main dining-room, 40 by go feet
in extent.

Union and you get 5,000,000 microscopic organisms at the same

when the water was taken ten feet
from the shore and a foot beneath
the surface. Water from the Ravenna Park sulphur springs was

The first two of a series of six
lectures on "The Romantic Revival
of Poetry in the Nineteenth Century" were delivered at 5 o'clock
last Thursday and Friday afternoons by Sir Walter Raleigh, professor of English poetry at Oxford
University. The lectures, which
dealt with the lives and works of
Coleridge and Keats, were greatly
enjoyed by large and appreciative
and
Sir Walter began his first lecture
with the statement that any study of
literature was concerned with but
two things of primal importance—
men and books. It was for this reason, he continued, that he had decided not to give an introductory
talk on the external influences that
helped to bring about the revival,
but had preferred to enter at once
upon the consideration of the part
played by one of the chief actors
in the movement—Samuel Taylor
Coleridge.
The lecturer dealt first with the
character of Coleridge, as revealed
in his letters. It was remarked that
the laziness and the tendency toward plagiarism that seriously affected the poet's literary career were
clearly foreshadowed in sonic of
these youthful epistles, for many of
their cleverest passages and aptest
phrases were filched outright from
letters of Thomas Gray. Coleridge's
earliest poems were then considered, and finally the period when
the element of the supernatural was
introduced into his work received
the attention of the speaker. It was
at this time that the poet seemed
suddenly to have found himself, for
all of his work that is of any great
degree of importance was composed
during the ten years immediately
ensuing.
Coleridge's relations with Wordsworth and Lamb were commented
upon, his friendship with the former being of chief importance because of the influence it exerted
upon his literary production. The
lecturer closed with an appreciation
of the work of Coleridge, and a consideration of the indebtedness of his
age and of the reading world of all
ages to the great Lake poet.
The discussion of the character
and writings of Keats was equally
adequate and appreciative. Sir
Walter first sought to dissipate the
general, though erroneous, impression that the brilliant, romantic poet
was an affected dandy like Leigh
Hunt and many another of his literary contemporaries. He showed that
Keats was a man of happy disposi-

The Johns Hopkins lacrosse team
played the Carlisle Indians to a
3-to-3 tie on Saturday at Homewood Field in a game lull of excitement and interest from whistle to
whistle. The Indians, although
fighting hard for the victory, seemed
to play rather listlessly, and it was
not until the last few minutes of the
contest that real fighting took place.
Hopkins made their first score well
on ill the game, this being followed
ouickly by the Indians' initial tally.
The ball was almost constantly in
the visitors' territory, and time and
again the Black and Blue men shot
for goal only to be confronted with
a disappointing-looking crowd of
redskins blocking the goal. Carlisle
seemed to be playing an entirely defensive game, barring such times as
when they would momentarily carry
the ball down the field and try for
goal. It was in times like these that
the invaluable services of Stuart, in
the goal, and 'Huck and Brooks, his
helpers, saved Hopkins from severe
punishment.
Many former lacrosse stars present at the game were disappointed
in the way the Hopkins men allowed
the ball to be taken from them without a "fight," but it was suggested
that perhaps this was caused by lack
Altogether, the
of confidence.
coaches were pleased by the showing of the team, and expect to have
a well-seasoned team in condition to
meet Navy and Pennsylvania this
week. Bob Nelson, the big center,
was a little "off his feed" Saturday,
but it is thought that by mid-season
he will prove himself a tower of
strength to the team. Among the
new men on the squad, \Volfe and
Woodward have shown up to advantage and both may land regular
jobs.

Prof. Dudley A. Sargent. of Harvard. does not favor military training for the youth of our schools or
the young men of our colleges, and
he is the best-known expert in scientific physical development in the
United States, if not in the world.
Th:s view puts him at an absolute
variance from Dr. Jacob Gould
Schurman, president of Cornell,
who declares that schools and colleges should be used as military
training- agencies, and who recently
has so expressed himself publicly,
thereby making something of a
sensation.
"A citizens' army for health and
efficiency," he said, "could do more
for our national defense than a
military army ever could do. for
we could include in that citizens'
army every, able-bodied male in
land, without curtailing his usefulness in industry, and his service in it would make his physically
ready for the brief military training
which would be necessary if need
arose for his service as a soldier.
There would be no sacrifice of him
upon the altar of militarism unless
necessity occurred.
"The expense of such an army for
health and efficiency," Professor
Sargent continued,"and what would
be accomplished by it, would be entirely out of proportion to the expense and accomplishments of our
present military force, the expense
being infinitely less and the accomplishments infinitely greater.
"The moment is now ripe for the
beginning of an organization of the
sort, rather than for the beginning
of a vast military organization. In
case of war it very quickly could be
rendered able to protect us better
than an army with purely military
training could. In the times of
peace, for which we hope and to
which we all look forward, it would
add more to our national wealth
than anything else could. I think
a peace army would be more acceptable, also, to the temper of the
American people, who often have
raised their voices against a great
standing military army.
"The weakness of the peace
movement always has been that it
never has offered a substitute for
the standing\ military army, and this
has worried those wise people who
have not wished to see our country
left utterly defenseless.
"Germany's theory was that without militarism her people would go
to seed, become flaccid. But the
reasoning on which she based this
theory took no thought of such an

Although the baseball team has
only one victory, with three defeats,
to its credit it has played well and
has in its first four games given
promise of developing into a wellbalanced machine that can land for
Hopkins the State championship.
The members of the Black and
Blue squad have shown themselves
especially strong at the bat. Several
men on the team are hitting the ball
at a most promising rate. "Butts"
Sutton has only played in two
games, but he has about five hits
to his credit, among which are several that went for extra bases.
Ewing is another slugger. He
made a home run against the Terrapins and another against the Aggies.
Noble and Worthington have also
shown up well with the bat.
Though beaten by Princeton, the
'Varsity put up a good game and
would probably have won if several
costly errors could have been avoided. Against the Baltimore Feds the
problem was to let the Terrapins
get as few runs as possible. Hopkins was, of course, outclassed, but
nevertheless played well and gained
valuable experience.
The team that met Catholic University was in a crippled condition
and did well to hold the Washington team to three runs. Butler, the
star first baseman, could not play
and several other valuable men were
unable to be in the game.
The 'Varsity showed up very well
against the Maryland Agricultural
College, coming out victors in a
hard-fought battle with a 7-to-6
score. It was the batting of Sutton,
Worthington and "Babe" Ewing;
that turned the. trick and gave Hopkins the long end of the score.
Coach Hooper has developed two
sterling pitchers in Phythyon and
Hollingsworth. These two men
have speed and a large assortment
of curves and, above all, can use
their heads. Defandorf, who pitched
last year, and Gorman have also
shown up well and should be able
to pitch winning ball whenever
called into the box.
On next Saturday the Hopkins
squad meets Washington College at
Homewood. Washington College
has a good team and a close game
is expected, but Coach Hooper feels
confident that his men are rounding
into form and will gain another
victory on that day.

Alumni Secretaries Meet.

The third annual meeting of the
Association of Alumni Secretaries
was held lately at Columbia and
Yale Universities with sixty-five
representatives present, representing
schools from New England, California, Texas and Louisiana. The
object of the association is "to bring
together once a year from all over
the country, the men who are directing the alumni work of American
colleges and universities for a discussion of their common problems
— the effective organization of
alumni sentiment, the publication of
alumni journals, and all other
means of promoting the university
interest by holding the institution
and its-graduates in an intimate relation."

The schedule of the Johns Hopkins summer courses for 1915 has
recently been issued. The catalogue shows both a more elaborate
selection of studies and a larger faculty than that offered in any of the
previous four years in which the
summer school has been in existence.
The chief loss to the summer
school will be found in the absence
of Prof. Robert M. Gay, of Goucher College, who enjoys the reputation of being one of the foremost
essayists since Lamb and whose
courses on the short story and on
the novel of the nineteenth century
were two of last year's most popular classes.
One of the most important and
gratifying announcements in regard
to the faculty is that John H. Latane is to give courses this summer.
Dr. Latane will offer graduate
courses in Latin-American history
and diplomacy, in international law
and in American history.
Courses will be offered this summer in biology, chemistry, education, English composition, English
literature, French, German, history,
Latin, manual training, mathematics,
music (in connection with the Peabody Conservatory), physics, playground and recreation, politics, psychology and Spanish.
Two graduates of Hopkins will
come from other universities to offer courses here this summer. Associate Professor Robert L. Ramsay, of the University of Missouri,
will give two courses in English
composition and one graduate
course in recent English literature,
and Associate Professor Asa A.
Schaeffer, of the University of Tennessee, will offer two courses in biology.
Prof. Edward F. Buchner will
again be the director of the summer
courses, and practically the same arrangements will be made in regard
to the credits given for work done
in these courses as were in existence
last year—that is to say, a credit of
not more than one-half a regular
course will be allowed for the satisfactory completion of the work of
any course of collegiate grade (only
two courses to be offered for
credit) ; and graduate courses will
be credited by the respective departments in accordance with the rule
of the Board of University Studies.
The tuition fee is twenty-five dollars, payment of which entitles the
student to attend as many as three
courses. There are no formal examinations for admission.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 12, 1915.
Shower Troubles.

Not so very long ago a member
of one of the spring teams stood
under the shower in the clubhouse
beneath the concrete stand at Homewood. He had just succeeded in
working up a fluffy lather from a
giant cake of soap and was about
to step under the spray when the
water ceased to flow. He worked
awhile at the spigots, but the pipes
were empty. Covered with soapsuds, he pondered awhile, then became indignant, and, failing to find
the ,English language expressive, began to speak in an old Semitic
tongue, which was a great revelation, as well as shock, to his hearers.
A committee of relief offered him
the little bit of water which remained in a drinking pail, and applying this with a ladle and by means
of a stiff piece of cardboard he
finally cleaned off the lather, and
went without the shower.
The caretaker of Homewood
Field said: "The water tank is
empty; it will take two hours to fill
it. You cannot take a bath today."
An inquiry into the state of affairs revealed the following facts:
That, notwithstanding the testimony
of the caretaker, there was water in
the tank, but that it had been turned
off until the members of another
team, which was still at practice,
had returned for their showers. So
those who had been affected by the

The announcement of an anonymous gift of $50,000 to the University came as a delightful surprise last week. It was not definitely announced whether the money
would be immediately available nor
whether it could be put into that
slowly-growing fund which will enable the building of the remainder
of the University's plant on the new
Homewood estate, but the very fact
that a Baltimorean (who does not
wish his name made public) is so
interested in our welfare as to give
us this sum of money at a time
when so much is needed reminds us
again of the fact that Baltimore is
working with the University and
wants to see it soon housed in
its magnificent new home in the
suburbs.
Fifty thousand dollars might not
mean much to the larger universities with great endowments and
regular -donors of princely sums."
To them it would he only a drop in
the bucket. But Hopkins, because
of its youth and consequent small
body of alumni, rarely receives a
gift of money except from some
educational foundation or under the
terms of the will of a friend. This
anonymous $50,000, then, means
much to the University. It brings
a message of friendship and collies
at a time when the institution, perhaps more than at any other time,
needs money. It lightens the hearts
of the men who are wrapped up in
the "on to Homewood" movement.
Because it expresses the esteem
in which the University is held by
"A Baltimorean," it is encouragement ; and, because it is encouragement, it is as greatly appreciated as
those great sums which are received
by other universities and colleges—
those large amounts which do not
make Hopkins envious, but which
spur it on to renewed activity with
the hope that some day it will be
in a position to call upon rich alumni
to satisfy every little wish and whim.

of Maine, has enrolled in one of the
short agricultural courses at the

To organize the Dartmouth undergraduates into an efficient body
for fire prevention, a student fire
squad has been appointed by Pal2eopitus and President Nichols. Nine
men selected from the junior class
will act with the members of Palx°piths as a fire squad.

To prevent political deals in the
elections of class officers and committee members at Brown, Dean
Randall has sent out pledges, to be
signed and returned to him. The
pledges are to the effect that the
signers will form no political parties
for the election of certain men or
groups of men.

Forty per cent, of the students in
the Kansas State Agricultural College get no financial aid from home.
The customary forms of employment are followed and several novel
ones. One of these novel plans
which has been adopted is the purchase of a cow by each of a group
of men, who receive their room and
board in return for the milk.
* * *
So great has been the recent
growth of the graduate college of the
University of Pennsylvania that the
present facilities for teaching professional courses are entirely inadequate, and plans are being made for
the erection of a building to cost
half a million dollars. The site of
the building is being cleared by the
razing of several ow structures.
* * *
-En order to save much of the time
now wasted by students in collecting money for undergraduate organizations, Prof. George Parmly
Day, treasurer of Yale University,
suggests a Student Collecting Association. Such an association would
continue from year to year the policy of efficient collecting, and in connection with the Bureau of Appointment, would assist students who
were in need of financial help.
* * *
Interest in track and field athletics at Cornell is not on the wane,
judging from a statement by Coach
Moakley at the recent track dinner.
He said that there are 310 candidates practicing regularly, and that
he expects an increase of 200 or
more. The coach also stated that he
considered track work excellent
training for those going into any
other line of college athletics, as it
typifies the perfect co-ordination of
all parts of the body.

PRESIDENT GOODNOW SPEAKS
TO ALUMNI OF MIDDLE WEST

President Goodnow left Baltimore last Wednesday on a short
trip through the Middle West, on
which he is to make addresses before Johns Hopkins alumni and
other organizations. Dr. Goodnow's first stop was Cleveland,
where he addressed the City Club
of that place.
Later, on invitation of Mayor
Newton Baker, of Cleveland, who is
himself an alumnus of Johns Hopkins, he addressed the Johns Hopkins alumni of Cleveland. On
Monday, President Goodnow attended the annual luncheon of the
Hopkins alumni of the Middle
West.
It is expected that through this
trip a new interest in the presentday Johns Hopkins and its activities will be created throughout the
sections in which alumni are located,
especially in view of the reconstructive period through which the University is now passing.
From the West, President Goodnow will go, later in the week, to
New York and will return to Baltimore shortly thereafter.

New York City's million-dollar
twenty-story Yale clubhouse is now
practically completed. This building, located at Vanderbilt avenue
and Forty-fourth street, wil soon be
the headquarters of all Yale men in
New York.
The main entrance to the buildnig is of simple design and the
ground floor will be used as an entrance hall and for offices. The
second floor contains a large social
hall—one of the noblest in New
York City. The third floor is given
up to billiard and grill rooms, the
fourth to a library, the fifth to the
swimming- pool and baths, the sixth
to the gymnasium and squash courts,
the seventh to a valeting- equipment.
Then follow ten floors of bedrooms.
The eighteenth floor contains numerous private dining-rooms of different sizes. Floor nineteen is the
kitchen department; floor twenty is
the main dining-room, 40 by go feet
in extent.

Drink a glass of water from Lake
Union and you get 5,000,000 microscopic organisms at the same
time. Drink a glass from Green
Lake and you reduce the number
2,000,000. Take a drink from Lake
Washington and the addition to
your internal population is but 150,000. • Such is the discovery of the
class in sanitary analysis in the University of Washington, working under the direction of Dr. John Weinzirl,• professor of bacteriology.
Sea water, the analysts found,
contained 2,000,000 micro-organisms
when the water was taken ten feet
from the shore and a foot beneath
the surface. Water from the Ravenna Park sulphur springs was
found to be almost sterile.
